instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01041: What is 820-01041? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP1V8_SLPS2R: What is PP1V8_SLPS2R? PP1V8_SLPS2R is a 1.8v power rail present when the system is in a SLPS2R state. .
definitions.PP5V_S5_LDO: What is PP5V_S5_LDO? PP5V_S5_LDO is a 5v rail present when the machine is in a S5 soft off state. .
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5V 0.38A
threads.message:
No liquid damage found on the board. 3 ports were going at 5v 0.42A replaced UB300 as it had a short to ground on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_TA_LDO</SIGNAL>. That is now cleared and I get 3.3v on that line.

The board is missing <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5_LDO</SIGNAL> (not sure if they are supposed to be present at 5v)

My main concern is <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> as this is showing in diode mode 0.008 ( 8.3ohms) should be 0.040 but when i apply usb power i get 1.8v on <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>

I hooked up my USB-C analyser and this gave me a fault to pin 33 on J3300 so i replaced <CHIP>U3000</CHIP> and that's now cleared. No other faults reported with the USB-C analyser.

I've tried DFU mode - failed

So i'm not sure if <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> is correct and why the reading is low.

All 4 ports are giving the same reading and there is no boot loop.

Any help is appreciated.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5V 0.38A
threads.message:
0.008 is too low for <SIGNAL>1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> power rail.
There is a problem for sure.
The correct voltage can be generated even with lower resistance than normal to ground.
But this denotes problems with something connected there.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5V 0.38A
threads.message:
Where would you suggest the problem is.. <CHIP>U3000</CHIP> or maybe <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>? This power line is used all over the board.

Is it going to me a matter of removing each component until it's found?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5V 0.38A
threads.message:
Inject 2V and use IR camera.
May help you to detect small temperature differences.
Remove CPU heatsink first.
You may need to wait several minutes...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5V 0.38A
threads.message: 2v?? the rail is only 1.8v is that safe to do?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5V 0.38A
threads.message:
No problem to inject 10% more.
You can try 1.5-1.8V, but will not be easy to detect temperature difference.
Even 2V may not help...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> stuck at 5V 0.38A
threads.message:
Prefect... Found the problem to be the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> (<CHIP>U3200</CHIP>). Replaced and now working again. 

Thank you for your help.
